text.quote: Exhibits on the technology & cultural history of Suzhou silk production & trade via the Silk Road.
trip: So first and foremost be aware if you don’t walk out with purchases it takes over 2 months for shipping. I purchased silk bedding with a free second blanket (silk). Along with 2 (silk) pillows. The tag on the pillows which is in Chinese says silk pillow, yet I had the rest
Small, interesting museum from the ancient history of silk to modern times. Includes working looms, beautiful silk fabric from thousands of years ago, and a good shop

My Wife and I visited the Suzhou Silk Culture Expo Museum along with our tour group when we were in Suzhou last month. We were treated to an excellent demonstration of all phases of the silk growing, processing, and manufacturing processes. We had hands-on experience with the

As part of our tour we were required to go to the silk museum and factory. It was interesting but I felt a little drawn out. After the tour in the factory you can but high quality silk at a good price.

There seems to be some confusion between the Silk museum and the factory that has silk items to sell - The Silk museum is a real museum with very good displays that explain how silk was discovered and the history of silk farming and weaving in China. In addition to the history

I was here as part of a tour group, so our guide gave us some explanations, but there are also some explanatory panels in English. This museum gave a complete explanation of the process for creating silk, from the mulberry plants outside the entrance, through to the pupas and
The museum does well to explain both the history of silk making and actually demonstrate it with looms weaving silk live. The building has a pleasing design
dont expect a tour of the museum, we were herded into a room & given the hard sell. The silk is lovely.

We were on an escorted tour so we got the full sales and benefits lecture first and it was certainly very entertaining. In fact the health benefits of silk are so numerous i was sorry i bought the green tea earlier in the trip because apparently silk can cure every ailment known

Not sure where else you can go (in the world?) to learn both the history of silk making and see it being done live. Truly eye opening! Yes, there is a shop at the end, but there was ZERO pressure to buy anything and it was actually nice to see some of the items that were

The museum is very interesting to see how silk has developed and how it is now made. The icing on the top is the items for sale the duvets, pillows, sheets, duvet covers are a terrific price and beautiful quality. Then there are th smaller items like the PJs and silk purses ,

Wanted to go to a factory, but when this was within walking distance of my Airbnb, in the shadow of the North Pagoda, this was just easier. We very much enjoyed the historical displays of when and where the silk was made with samples of original silk and well as reproductions of
We had the tour AND the sales pitch, but was still interesting, The store was a good stop, you can get good prices on real silk products. Good variety of scarfs and ties.

Some people feel like tour is commercialized at the end. What do you expect? Not to buy silk? I loved going through the stations and seeing how silkworks were raised, cultivated, and then used to separate the strands of gold. I did not expect the hands on experience of

It's a small museum but worth an hour visit, relaxing walking around to see the demonstration of how people making silk. A small room with the book written in French of the lady who brought the silk business to a higher level. A small exhibition of some dynasty's costume made

This was an informative tour of how silk is made and I enjoyed it as part of our tour. Very much geared for selling with a large retail area and plenty to purchase, clothes and bedding. I actually bought a silk duvet which is really good and much cheaper than I would pay at home.

Listen carefully to the tour guide and what is being said from the guide. The story is interesting and the products on offer for purchase are lovely and most people purchase something to remember their visit.
interesting place but more for sales to tourists organised by travel company, not somewhere you would visit as an individual person touring china

We were bought here as part of an organised tour. It was interesting to see from start to finish how silk is produced and woven into the beautiful products you can purchase at the store at the end of tour. Pricing was good for true silk. Building sits within a lovely little

This was a memorable experience. We saw the process of making silk and had hands-on experience with the pulling of the silk. They have a room for purchasing bedding, a place for clothes, and a room for souvenirs. I didn't find anyone to push a sale on you and the prices were

The museum was very nice. History of the silk industry was educational. Linens were exquisite and very nice. Pricing was reasonable. Shipping was a bit slow. They had free shipping but by boat. I think they were rowing all the way.

We were left in the capable hands of an English speaking guide, and she took us through all the different processes of silk harvesting and weaving. She was very knowledgeable, and made it all seem interesting. When we got to the shop none of the staff were pushy, some telling
I lost count on how many silk factories I visited over the last four trips to China. This is pretty much the same-so.

Very interesting place to visit. We went with a tour company and after a brief demonstration and walk around tour you are then led to the showroom to buy silk items. This silk museum is operated by the Chinese government. The sales staff is very friendly but not pushy at all.

A visit to the museum shows how wonderful silk can be used to create beautiful artefacts and clothing. Some of it was quite amazing. Tour a little rushed with a closely following group. Once tour over chance to purchase silk clothing and artefacts.

Nice little museum, and also a working spinning shop that you can walk into and take video of ladies spinning silk. The store seemed over priced and we did not buy anything. The tour we were on used the neighboring restaurant as part of their collaboration effort. Fun little
great place, had a tour about the silkworms and was amazed about how long a piece of silk can go for, bought some silk items, very good tour
I recomend it combined with a nice long walk in the old-town of Suzhou. 60-90 minutes is quite enough if you are not an expert of the topic.
It was interesting to learn about how silk is made. The shopping is good and they do not pressure you.

We were rushed through the tour and not shown much. I presume that was done so more of our allotted time there could be spent shopping. Bedding is available very good prices. Clothing - be ware to know the material. Not all clothing there is made of silk.
It was a pretty cool stop on our tour. We learned how silk is made from the start of the process to the end.

Formerly an actual factory which helps make this place authentic. We have visited a number of silk making exhibits and this is by far the best. It even has mulberry trees on site. Lots to buy as well. Quality is fine but prices are fairly firm. I got my discount but I
this is a very interesting place to visit, seeing how they get the silk fibers out of the cacoons, to make such beautiful garments

Silk Museum is a must visit place when you are in Suzhou. I enjoyed learning how silk road started and spent hours here at the gallery reading the history of silk and looking at the exhibits, then walked through an arched red door into a beautifully landscaped mulberry garden.

You can learn almost everything about silk. You can meet the caterpillars, look at the leafs, cocoon, way of production. It is the traditional production line of silk - very interesting to see! And, of course, at the end you pass a big silk mall. I suppose everybody can find and

Although there was a very impressive display and education of the cycle of silk production and silken products, this is essentially a retail outlet selling high priced items under guise of "emperor quality". No doubt th equality wa shigh, but so were the prices. there was also
well organized and nicely presented, detailed information available in English for international traveller. Must visit place when go to Suzhou.

The visit to the Suzhou Silk Museum was such a great experience for the kids. They got to see so many silk worms eating delicious Mulberry Leaves. The place is surprisingly clean and quite open for us to simply walk around and explore, which was great. We also saw silk workers

You can observed how the silk is produced from the first phase. If you wish you can touch even larvas :) Of course, there is obligatory silk shop after the visit. Fortunately nobody is pressed to buy something.

While most tours might take you to a factory for purchasing silk, this museum tells a great story about silk in China and makes for a great stop while in town exploring Suzhou. The exhibits are all well done and the museum is free. Definitely worth a stop.

Wow !!!!very friendly staff and great staff .Just wonderful information.Wonderful silk products. I got a beautiful scarf ,socks and underwear . Bought my husband a beautiful shirt . He said it’s very comfortable. So much information about the silk worms 🐛.So great learnt a lot
This was a quick and worthwhile stop to see how silk is made, from the worms to the looms. The store/gift shop is large and takes away from the experience a little, but still worth it.

We visited here as part of our tour, and I was pleasantly surprised by the information. I'd never heard of some of the items being made from silk and how apparently good they are. Needless to say I have come home with a silk quilt!!

So as part of a tour we went to the silk factory Our host was hilarious Very good sense of humour but she could sell like no other The products are incredibly cheap and you can grab a bargain They even throw in a suitcase to bring it home in Look it was interesting If you

Our tour guide provided us an in depth view of how silk is produced and turned into products. It is a government owned factory. We had plenty of time to tour and shop - no overt pressure to buy at all. We ended up purchasing several items as gifts for family and friends and

Museum shows how silkworm grows, is harvested and how silk is produced.. Good learning experience.. Goods are very expensive.. Courier service is available which delivers your purchase to the address given .. Good visit..
We marvelled at the intricate craftsmanship in designing and manufacturing premier quality bedding, apparel, and artwork. And it’s possible to buy them from the excellent in-house retail outlet.

I have mixed feelings about our time at the silk museum. It was very busy and had several groups going through while we were there, so we only got the chance to briefly see 'the making of silk'. We were able to touch some single and double cocoons, see a map of the silk road,
Tour guide said this is an average place to see but we found this to be one of the best things in Suzhou as we did not grade the gardens with any stars
Nice museum, But we stayed here for Too many hours. It’s a bit a tourist trap. The people who worked here are friendly And nice people!
This was an interesting museum with a comprehensive outline of the history of silk and how it is made.

The silk museum is an interesting place. The tour shows you the lifecycle of the silk worm (live action) how the silk is harvested, cleaned, spun, dyed and woven into cloth. There is a fashion show of silk products which is also strangely interesting and finally to obligatory

We went there not expecting too much but spent 2 hours there with great interest. It's a little gem to know the history of silk and the development of Suzhou as an important silk-fabric manufacturing centre in China. This place is easily accessible by metro which is just

We arrived to be greeted by a lady who took us on the tour, we saw how the eggs turn to a larvae and then spins a cocoon in silk thread the farmers then heats up the cocoon to kill the grub before it starts to eat it’s way outta turn into moth. Every cocoon gives approximately 1

I would like to have seen more of the manufacturing aspect but we were given a short demonstration and an interesting talk. The sales staff here were not high pressure, unlike the pearl and jade factories.

This was part of our shopping tour. Some brief history of the silk worm but this is geared more to actual selling of what seem overpriced items. Still not a bad experience but not something I would do again.

Hmm I am a bit divided about this one. In choosing what I wanted to do in Suzhou, I decided to go to the museum as I thought it would be interesting and I would see a lot about silk. I went to the museum and, upon entering, found it to be initially interesting as I could
Beautiful silk but feels like you're in a shopping channel. Buy one get one free, but wait there's more!!. You can buy what looks like the same thing cheaper at the markets.

The visit starts very promissing and you learn how silk is made from the cocoons of the silkworm. There are also a number of interesting weaving machines on dispkay. But then you enter in a commetcial area which is much larger than the museum. Although the staff is not pushing

Another selling spot on our Nexus tour. Our guide gave us an interesting talk on the process of making silk and we watched as the silk was taken from the cucooon thread by thread to make skeins which can than be used for embroidery. Saw some lovely "paintings" done in silk but

The first part of our visit described the life cycle of the silk worm and how silk was produced and made into a usable product. This was very interesting and hands on. The second part was the shop area where bedding and clothing was being sold. Worth a visit and no hassle from

Well if you'd like to know and see a little of how real silk is produced, this is the place. They tell you about silk worms and mulberry bushes. They show you the process from cocoon to quilt, then usher you through the factory to a large shop selling everything silk, and a

Had a tour of the museum that included a presentation on how silk is made and turned into material. Part of the presentation was interactive. Also included a visit to the museum's shop where pillows, bedcovers, clothing, etc could be purchased.

Loved learning the history and culture behind the silk industry in Suzhou, how much silk is obtained from a single cocoon and they use the double cocoons to make the silk doonas. The most exquisite silk coats but way too expensive for me

After visiting gardens the silk museum was worth having a look at. The process of getting the silk from the cocoons and spinning is interesting. As usual there is a overpriced gift shop. But it is a good way to kill an hour or more especially if you are looking for an indoor

The silk museum is more about the history of the manufacture of silk, but there are some really nice exhibits of ancient and modern garments. It's an indoor/outdoor, very modern space that's worth exploring just for the building.

Interesting visit which looks at the history of silk manufacturing and on silk importance through the various dynasties. Equipment from the silk industry and live silkworms on display. Air conditioned museum with a nice little coffee shop in the centre. Nice layout. Worth a

Surprisingly, almost all exhibits in the main part of the museum were translated perfectly into English. Only when you go out to the outer buildings are the exhibits in Chinese only. Still, if you want to get a good lesson in silk production and with timelines etc, it's a nice
If you are interested in silk and like to know about the history and production, this location is a MUST. Bring time and learn a bit before you go to get the full experience.

The Suzhou Silk Museum is a bit of a Hidden Gem, an amazing place in the historic Silk Capital of the World. Don't miss this place, because it should visited by everyone interested in the region. All this and no lines, a 1 kilometer walk from the Suzhou Museum and the Humble

An absolute must it is really interesting and the silk there is from outstanding quality not really cheap but top quality. Very friendly people and a must if you like to know more about the silk still made as it was hundred years ago.It seems that Suzhou got the best silk of

If you want to learn more about the production of silk in China, you should pay a visit to this museum. No entrance fee and it opens until 5 pm daily. High educational contents well suited for school going kids. You can see and touch the mulberry tree and the silkworm!

The museum is excellent if you like this kind of thing and you can actually see how silk items are produced right in front your eyes. Then you can buy just about everything in silk in very good prices.
U will learn how the silk material is form and the olden time, how the art and craft for embordary. How different the silk machine look as compare to the modern days sewing machine.
The silk museum was a surprise. It explains the history and manufacturing of silk in China. It has explanations in English and is completely free.

Doesn't look like much from the outside, but well done! Lots of English signage, relatively few people, interesting displays, well lite, and clean. Good for those who want a little history, some fashion, and so on. Even has a small coffee/snack shop.

On arrival at this place, do not be misled by a tout outside who will direct you to the nearby factory shop - although you might wish to see that also. The museum is a modern white complex of 3 buildings. The central one is the main one and covers ancient silk: is its history

Suzhou Silk Museum is located on Renmin Lu. The museum exhibition is considered one of the best in China. It tells the story of filature in Suzhou from the IV century BC to the present day. Local guides say that the greatest impression on visitors makes room filled with

No choice. I visited to try to find a man shirt for me. Only 3. And not my size ( medium ). Design horrible and 1 500 CNY. Or 180 €. Around 200 US $. At 1 km I found many very nice at 200 CNY or 26 €. In real silk, I am sure, from the brand I know since 10 years. In theese
Showed how they made silk from the cocoons through to the finished garments, ending with beautiful products that are of course, for sale. A little on the expensive side though.
There are just enough English descriptions so you understand the exhibits. This museum is well done and a must see if you are interested in the silk industry.

Was included in our tour - you see the process from the silkworm, the culling of the yellow silk from the cream which is then spun and threaded. Saw how the silk is used in the manufacture of clothing but what was really interesting was how the silk doonas were made. Yes, I
I have visited it twice and have brought several silk blankets, a lot of things made from silk or from silk with wool

I visited this attraction in August 2016 on a Nexus 10 Day sampler tour. Our tour leader was Fei and Joanne. After the tour we were offered to buy silk duvets, pillows etc. I was the only New Zealander but several Australians purchased items. Mine cost $500NZ approx. and I had
If you wondering and want know how silk come this museum right place for that and also show you history of made silk in Suzhou
interesting information but info given is very superficial. The aim for this facility is to get you to buy the silk duvets and silk garments and scarves.

Nothing impressive over here but was made to follow along as part of the package tour itinerary. Suzhou is indeed famous for their silk since ancient times. Here, you see brief introduction to how silk is being made but the main activities here are sales of their silk products.

I would never have thought of visiting a silk museum, but once my host took me there, I thought it was really cool. You get to see the entire process, from the silkworms to the machines that pull the silk from the cocoons, through the final manufacturing of silk goods. I learned

I am not sure whether this is the place whereby the so called museum operators and the tour guide will work hand in hand to persuade visitors to buy the silk blanket, pillows etc. Every time travel to China, the tour guides will give you a full ear that they do not receive any

Just before we embarked on our 14 day family vacation the grandchildren reported that they needed to do a written report on what they saw in China for their school. I remembered seeing the Silk Museum being an option and asked to have it included . It was definitely worth the

This was part of our tour of China . The visit was interesting it gave the history of the silk industry and how it is manufactured. The guide was very interesting and you were given time to look at materials you could purchase

The Silk museum is free, and shows in detail the process of silk-making and processing including a few live silkworms and a mock-up of a typical farmhouse. It also show original and replicated pieces of silk from ancient to modern, and historical garments. I found it very

this was a group visit as part of our tour in China, very informative and well laid out, lots to see and you could get close up for photos, seeing the silk worm caterpillars munching on mulberry leaves and then the cocoons being dropped in boiling water to eventually be 'unspun'

We visited not expecting much but this museum was very interesting. The live demonstrations show how difficult the process is and the amazing examples on show give you a feel for how amazing the early works would have been at the time

Really interesting museum to visit and learn about the silk history in China, also amazing old mechanism that was used for the silk industry, one with two woman still operating it. Would be great if someone was there to help explain what and how it works, but impressive to see
Went as part of a tour group, informative and ideally suited as a rainy day option. Selection of high quality products from shop, although there are lower price gifts nearer the exit.
Good to know and to see the different stages of the silkworms and how blankets were being made from it.

The tour was included in a garden tour we got. It was at the end of the garden tour so a number of younger guys opted out and left the group to explore the surrounding areas on foot. However, if you have children with you I would recommend going on the tour as you learn much

Near the museum entrance, a bunch of men were hell bent on us going to the "real museum" which turned out to be 3 rooms on the silk making process that led into a giant silk store with no exits! We then went to the real silk museum--amazing to see thousand + year remnants of
A place for you to buy silk products. I bargained and bought quite some silk products which are cheap and with many freebies.

Got to see the entire process of silk worms from incubation to the production of silk and have the ongoing pleasure of owning one of the silk comforters they proudly sell. I would stick to the comforters however some of the other silk items not so great. But the comforter well

You are able to view all the steps of the silk making process. We got to watch how they make duvet Inners which was amazing the lady's are nice. You are able to purchase silk at the end but there is no pressure. We went as a tour group so unsure if there is a cost to enter

Much less touristy than the gardens so head here if you are fed up with the crowds. I think some of the reviewers have confused the Silk Museum with one of the silk factories that happens to be a couple buildings to the left. Make sure you are at the Suzhou Silk Museum - it

Place slightly run down not many people visit this place but it was an interesting visit to this place showing the entire lifecycle of silk. The initial walk at the beginning helps you understand how silk started in SuZhou. Followed by ancient display of the machinery and

Our driver brought us here to do some shopping. He quickly found a staff member who could speak English and took us through the museum. However, she rushed us as this would have been a great place to spend more time. She was interested in getting us to the store to shop. Nice

It's a tourist trap- you purchase a trip, e.g. ,Suzhou gardens' and they take the whole bus to do the shopping there .. Bus after bus, hundreds of tourists. Of course the have a semi-guide who runs across the museum/exhibition part to stop at the shop where you can buy silk

I was taken here as part of a tour. They take tourist here to shop, the "workers" in the factory are just actors. Its actually a shiny shop with lots of silk product that have questionable quality. I ended up buying a pillow So they will leave us alone.
We had fun here. The guide was very good. More of a shopping opportunity that a museum but a very nice shopping opportunity. Did learn plenty of things we did not know.

I loved how visual the museum was and that you could see alive silk worms and people weaving silk. I just wish the explanations in English were better and that you could see how the worms produce silk. The museum was also free :).

Pouring rain today so we went to check out this museum as we knew it was indoors. So happy we went. Our family has an 11 year old and a 6 year old. Adults and kids were equally impressed with this world class museum. So much to see including four people operating two old
Very interesting seeing how silk is made, authentic way to learn about silk, there is also a shop where you can buy silk items and doona's. Great experience.

Based on the reviews here as well as that published in Lonely Planet, it appears that I may have been taken to a different location. So, please take that into account in considering my review. If nothing else, make sure that you get to the Silk MUSEUM. -- perhaps your

Getting to know the process of making the silk is very interesting and it is shown in the good way, you can see the process from the beginning through the machines used up to the final product. However the products which can you can buy in the shop are a little bit expensive.

We travelled with a tour and this was a compulsory stop. As is normal with these sorts of tours, it never seems to amaze me that they allow unlimited time at these "shopping tours", yet limit time at none shopping tours sites. As it goes though, it was informative. Our guide

We enjoyed learning about the whole process of making silk and seeing the modern process in action, from mulberry plants growing, so caterpillars eating the leaves, to spinning and weaving. The variety of finished products are lovely but expensive.

We were the only patrons in this beautiful museum. It is worth an hour or two of your time. Signage is plentiful in English. We loved seeing live silkworms and listening to them eating their mulberry leaves. It is near the silk factory, but we did not have time to go there.

Initially I had some concerns about sending a significant amount of money to a company that was based in China and had no presence in the west, but these fears were completely unfounded. Odyssey Tours were fabulous and our consultant - Reinself Wei was exceptionally efficient,

Visited Silk Museum with my family and my daughter, 6 years old, really enjoyed to learn how its production works. Wel-trained English Speaker guide was available. At the end, of course, we have an opportunity to buy silk products and its price is very reasonable unlike the
If you want to see how those silk scarfs are made and the long standing history of Chinese craft, truly recommend to visit the silk museum.

Interesting visit learning about the history of Chinese silk making. Lots of beautiful silk garments to view and a demonstration of how silk is woven into such beautiful patterns. It was a nice little stopover on our tour.
Went there and was surprised about how much you can learn about silk from the worms to the thread to the fabric in this place definitely worth a visit!

There are tours that go through here, due to what i assume was a mistranslation/miscommunication the people here hastily walked us through the museum to the shopping area of the museum. We simply walked back around and looked through the museum on our own (its pretty small).

A must go for anyone wanting to understand how silk a are produce from silkworm. A very old traditional weaving machine is still been display on site thus making it interesting to watch. Great shopping items are on sales at the end of the tour and great value for monies in
Very informative, not that much of a tour but vast silk shopping area. There is also a restaurant on premises. Overall good your stop, not a special on your own stop.

If you are on a tour you are required to stop at this factory. That, however, may be a good thing for some people, because they wouldn't come here otherwise. It provides an interesting look at how silk is made, and also provides many opportunities to buy silk. The quality is

This facility is government owned and operated and a required stop for tour companies. Interesting to see the silk worms "at work" and the machines used to create silk masterpieces. The store at the end does have high quality, seemingly value priced garments and bedding.
This is a major tourist trap but why not make a stop, it was fairly interesting to learn a bit about silk and compared to prices I would pay back home the prices were excellent.

This silk factory has always been part of the Shanghai tour itinerary. The silk mattress protector and blankets are the favourite products for tourists to bring home. The quality is pretty good too. But remember to wash them with shampoo and not other detergents. You could
It is interesting to see how the silk is produced but in my opinion nothing too spectacular. In the end, there is a shop where you can buy silk products.

We toured. The. Factory seeing how silk was made from worm to fabric, it was fascinating. We saw some young ladies doing some fabulous embroidery, on of the ladies was making a picture that was totally different on each side. The visit finishes in the shop, as it almost always

Recommend this attraction as it is a visit one would not really put on their itinery. We all know about silk worms from school but this visit showed how the factory worked, exquisite silk paintings were selling for thousands of dollars. The workmanship on these paintings was

Was a nice place to visit, but still seemed exceptionally high in price. Really hard to believe that it takes that much to process silk. The tour was fun, but did get a little long as we had been through other silk tours in other countries.
We enjoyed our visit to the Silk Museum. It was great to see the worms feeding, the thread being extracted from the cocoons, the spinning and the weaving process.

Yes, this feels like a major tourist trap, but the museum part and the demonstrations were actually fascinating. I have never seen nor touched silk worms, nor have I had any understanding of how silk is actually harvested. This visit turned out to be quite fascinating.

Although silk is made the same way in most places, it is always great to see the individual twists that are put into the displays and in this case - they are amazing!! The history of China's silk - and Suzhou's in particular - is breath-taking in its fantastic display cabinets;
What a great stop. Beware, they are looking to sell Silk. If you are looking to buy, this is the place. The tours are great and staff is friendly and answers many questions.

The original museum, recommended on multiple guides and websites is, unfortunately, closed. If you stop by you will be brought in a fake silk museum nearby just for the sake of some expensive shopping.

Fascinating tour, only to be lead to a sales area with inflated prices. Ok for those who love silk, as it is all good quality, but if you're not into it, can't wait to get on with the rest of the day.

I have been here many times and i alway enjoy the history and seeing how the silk is used to make thread and quits and fabric. There is a small store where you can by sheets, comforters and other silk items. Its a must see

I went there 31/5/2015. Found out that they are in big upgrade and renovation. We decided to go to other silk factory. Someone show us the way. I not sure whether we are being cheated or not. May be u can call before u go. Tq.

The tour of the museum was very interesting. The English speaking guide is very good. We were showed the entire silk making process. I really enjoyed the tour. Upon completion of the tour, we were guided to the shop where they sold all the Silk products. Nowadays, we can buy
Good to know how to find out the difference between original and fake silk. Start from the worm, cocoon and see how they make quilts, pillows and others
It's a great way to see and understand how they produce silk products. It's not a long tour, they will explain step by step and by the end you can buy real silk products with fair price. Recommended!

This museum was unexpectedly interesting with a nice display on silk production, machines to make silk thread and artisans working with silk. Of course there was a showroom where all sorts of silk products were available for sale. We had purchased products made by this same

Hi we planned to go to the museum yesterday. When we arrived the museum was closed for construction (november 2014). We have no idea when it will be open again. At the tourist information they not even knew that the museum was currently closed........

We stopped here as part of a tour and I was mentally prepared for yet another hard sell for stuff I don't really need. But the exhibition and museum were very interesting. We saw the silk thread being unraveled from the cocoons and double cocoons being stretched over frames to

To see a mock process of getting silk from mulberry bushes this is interesting and it was a very colourful shop in which many of us bought silk duvets which were well packaged and easily managed by our Tour. Besides the large items we saw all the small purses in masses which

This is one of those, never really thought about it before type places which you are glad to have visited. We all know silk and generally how it is produced, but seeing it all in action was really eye-opening, from how they find the end of the ‘thread’ to 5-6 in the water bath

Its called a musuem but its really a working factory that the govt uses to attract tourists. But, that's not to say it wasn't interesting. They start off showing you how silk is produced, live silk worms, how its collected and so on. The tour stops in a silk shop so you can

text.wiki:
The Tiger Hill Pagoda, more officially the Yunyan Pagoda (Chinese: 云岩寺塔; pinyin: Yún yán sì tǎ; Suzhou Wu: Yuin nge zy thaeh, Wu Chinese pronunciation: [ɦʏn ŋe̞ zz̩ tʰɑʔ] or Chinese: 虎丘塔; pinyin: Hŭ qiū tǎ; Suzhou Wu: Hou chieu thaeh, Wu Chinese pronunciation: [hou tɕʰʏ tʰɑʔ]), also sometimes translated as Huqiu Tower, is a Chinese pagoda situated on Tiger Hill in Suzhou city, Jiangsu Province of Eastern China. It is nicknamed the 'Leaning Tower of China'.


== History ==
The primary pagoda of the former Yunyan Temple, which was founded in 327 and rebuilt for the last time in 1871. The temple suffered damage in successive wars and most of the temple was destroyed during the Second Sino-Japanese War. Some elements of the temple such as the formal entrance, the Yunyan Pagoda, and several other buildings and smaller shrines have survived, and now stand as landmarks throughout Tiger Hill Park. 
Construction of the pagoda began in 907 CE, during the later period of the Five Dynasties period, at a time when Suzhou was ruled by the Wuyue Kingdom. Construction was completed in 961 CE during the Song Dynasty.The uppermost stories of the pagoda were built as an addition during the reign of the Chongzhen Emperor (1628–1644), the last emperor of the Ming Dynasty.


== Description ==
The Yunyan Pagoda rises to a height of 47 m (154 ft). The pagoda has seven stories and is octagonal in plan, and was built with a masonry structure designed to imitate wooden-structured pagodas prevalent at the time. 


=== Leaning tower ===
In more than a thousand years the pagoda has gradually slanted due to forces of nature. Now the top and bottom of the tower vary by 2.32 meters. The entire structure weighs some 7,000,000 kilograms (15,000,000 lb), supported by internal brick columns. However, the pagoda leans roughly 3 degrees due to the cracking of two supporting columns.The pagoda leans because the foundation is originally half rock and the other half is on soil. In 1957, efforts were made to stabilize the pagoda and prevent further leaning. Concrete was also pumped into the soil forming a stronger foundation. 
During the reinforcement process, a stone casket containing Buddhist scriptures was found. The container had an inscription noting the completion date of the pagoda as the seventeenth day of the twelfth month of the second year of the Jianlong era (961 CE).


== Present day ==
The Yunyan Pagoda is a designated Major National Historical and Cultural Site in Jiangsu.  As of September 2010 public access to the top of the tower is no longer allowed.


== Notes ==


=== References ===
Ingles, O.G. "Impressions of a Civil Engineer in China," The Australian Journal of Chinese Affairs (Number 7, 1982): 141–150.


== See also ==
Song Dynasty architecture
Major national historical and cultural sites (Jiangsu)

I have been going to Tiger Hill for Years. Having lived in Suzhou I would seek out the solitude and tranquility that this ancient yet beautiful spot would give me. Stressed from the office I would go mid week when few crowds were there. Wander the ancient buildings and places.

The whole surrounding of the Garden is wonderful and it is very comfortable to walk either
There is so much to see here. Lovely flowers and buildings. There were an awful lot of people here but it is possible to find a bit of space occasionally. Definately a "must visit" though!
Great place to get away. Like most of the sites in Suzhou you need to get away from the beaten path to find some space. Relaxing space away from the city center

A pleasant escape from the business of Downtown Suzhou. Lots of other visitors but more space to roam!
This was the third lot of gardens we had been to and we were over the milling crowds, however this garden was exceptionally beautiful.

text.wiki:
Suzhou (Chinese: 苏州; Suzhounese pronunciation: [səu tsøʏ], Standard Mandarin pronunciation: [sú.ʈʂóu]), alternately romanized as Soochow, is a major city located in southeastern Jiangsu Province of East China, about 100 km (62 mi) northwest of Shanghai. It is a major economic center and focal point of trade and commerce, and the second largest city in the province, after its capital Nanjing. The city is situated on the lower reaches of the Yangtze River and the shores of Lake Tai and belongs to the Yangtze River Delta region. Administratively, Suzhou is a prefecture-level city with a population of 4.33 million in its city proper, and a total resident population (as of 2013) of 10.58 million in its administrative area. Its urban population grew at an unprecedented rate of 6.5% between 2000 and 2014, which is the highest among cities with more than 5 million people.Founded in 514 BC, Suzhou has over 2,500 years of history, with an abundant display of relics and sites of historical interest. Around AD 100, during the Eastern Han dynasty, it became one of the ten largest cities in the world mostly due to emigration from Northern China. Since the 10th-century Song dynasty, it has been an important commercial center of China. During the Ming and Qing dynasties, Suzhou was a national economic, cultural, and commercial center, as well as the largest non-capital city in the world, until the 1860 Taiping Rebellion. When Li Hongzhang and Charles George Gordon recaptured the city three years later, Shanghai had already taken its predominant place in the nation. Since major economic reforms began in 1978, Suzhou has become one of the fastest growing major cities in the world, with GDP growth rates of about 14% in the past 35 years. With high life expectancy and per capita incomes, Suzhou's Human Development Index ratings is roughly comparable to a moderately developed country, making it one of the most highly developed and prosperous cities in China.The city's canals, stone bridges, pagodas, and meticulously designed gardens have contributed to its status as one of the top tourist attractions in China. The Classical Gardens of Suzhou were added to the list of the UNESCO World Heritage Sites in 1997 and 2000. Suzhou is often dubbed the "Venice of the East" or "Venice of China".


== Names ==
During the Zhou, a settlement known as Gusu after nearby Mount Gusu (simplified Chinese: 姑苏山; traditional Chinese: 姑蘇山; pinyin: Gūsūshān) became the capital of the state of Wu. From this role, it also came to be called Wu as well. In 514 BC, King Helü of Wu established a new capital nearby at Helü City and this grew into the modern city. During the Warring States period, Helü City continued to serve as the local seat of government. From the areas it administered, it became known as Wuxian (lit. "Wu County") and Wujun ("Wu Commandery"). Under the Qin, it was known as Kuaiji after its greatly enlarged commandery, which was named for the reputed resting place of Yu the Great near modern Shaoxing in Zhejiang.
The name Suzhou was first officially used for the city in AD 589 during the Sui dynasty. The sū (蘇 or 苏) in its name is a contraction of the old name Gusu. It refers to the mint perilla (shiso). The zhou 州 originally meant something like a province or county (cf. Guizhou), but often came to be used metonymously for the capital of such a region (cf. Guangzhou, Hangzhou, etc.). Suzhou is the Hanyu Pinyin spelling of the Putonghua pronunciation of the name. Prior to the adoption of pinyin, it was variously romanized as Soo-chow, Suchow, or Su-chow.


== History ==
Suzhou, the cradle of Wu culture, is one of the oldest towns in the Yangtze Basin. By the Spring and Autumn period of the Zhou, local tribes named the Gou Wu are recorded living in the area which would become the modern city of Suzhou. These tribes formed villages on the edges of the hills above the wetlands surrounding Lake Tai.
Sima Qian's Records of the Grand Historian records traditional accounts that the Zhou lord Taibo established the state of Wu at nearby Wuxi during the 11th century BC, civilizing the local people and improving their agriculture and mastery of irrigation. The Wu court later moved to Gusu within the area of modern Suzhou. In 514 BC, King Helü of Wu relocated his court nearby and called the settlement Helü City after himself. His minister Wu Zixu was closely involved with its planning and it was this site that grew into present-day Suzhou. The height of his tower on Gusu Hill (Gusutai) passed into Chinese legend. In 496 BC, King Helü was buried at Tiger Hill. In 473 BC, Wu was defeated and annexed by Yue, a kingdom to its southeast; Yue was annexed in turn by Chu in 306 BC. Remnants of the ancient kingdom include pieces of its 2,500-year-old city wall and the gate through it at Pan Gate.
The city was originally laid out according to a symbolic three-by-three grid of nine squares, with the royal palace occupying the central position.During the Warring States period, Suzhou was the seat of Wu County and Commandery. Following the Qin Empire's conquest of the area in 222 BC, it was made the capital of Kuaiji Commandery, including lands stretching from the south bank of the Yangtze to the unconquered interior of Minyue in southern Zhejiang. Amid the collapse of the Qin, Kuaiji's governor Yin Tong attempted to organize his own rebellion only to be betrayed and executed by Xiang Liang and his nephew Xiang Yu, who launched their own rebellion from the city.
When the Grand Canal was completed, Suzhou found itself strategically located on a major trade route. In the course of the history of China, it has been a metropolis of industry and commerce on the southeastern coast of China. During the Tang dynasty, the great poet Bai Juyi constructed the Shantang Canal (better known as "Shantang Street") to connect the city with Tiger Hill for tourists. In AD 1035, the Suzhou Confucian Temple was founded by famed poet and writer Fan Zhongyan. It became a venue for the imperial civil examinations and then developed into the modern Suzhou High School in the 1910s.

In February 1130, the advancing Jin army from the north ransacked the city. This was followed by the Mongol invasion in 1275. In 1356, Suzhou became the capital of Zhang Shicheng, one of the leaders of the Red Turban Rebellion against the Yuan dynasty and the self-proclaimed King of Wu. In 1367, Zhang's Nanjing-based rival Zhu Yuanzhang took the city after a 10-month siege. Zhu – who was soon to proclaim himself the first emperor of the Ming Dynasty – demolished the royal city in the center of Suzhou's walled city and imposed crushing taxes on the city and prefecture's powerful families. Despite the heavy taxation and the resettlement of some of Suzhou's prominent citizens' to the area of Hongwu's capital at Nanjing, Suzhou was soon prosperous again. During the early Ming, Suzhou Prefecture supervised the Yangtze shoals which later became Shanghai's Chongming Island. For centuries the city, with its surroundings as an economic base, represented an extraordinary source of tax revenue.When the shipwrecked Korean official Choe Bu had a chance to see much of Eastern China from Zhejiang to Liaoning on his way home in 1488, he described Suzhou in his travel report as exceeding every other city. Many of the area's private gardens were constructed by the gentry of the Ming and Qing dynasties. The Taipings captured the city in 1860, however, and many of its former buildings and gardens were "almost... a heap of ruins" by the time of their recovery by Charles Gordon's Ever-Victorious Army in November 1863. Nonetheless, by 1880, its population was estimated to have recovered to about 500,000, which remained stable for the next few decades. In the late 19th century, the town was particularly known for its wide range of silks and its Chinese-language publishing industry. The town was first opened to direct foreign trades by the Treaty of Shimonoseki ending the First Sino-Japanese War and by the most favored nation clauses of earlier unequal treaties with the Great Powers. The new expatriates opened a European-and-Chinese school in 1900 and the Suzhou railway station, connecting it with Shanghai, opened on July 16, 1906. Just prior to the World War I, there were 7000 silk looms in operation, as well as a cotton mill and a large trade in rice.

As late as the early 20th century, much of the city consisted of islands connected by rivers, creeks, and canals to the surrounding countryside. Prior to their demolition, the city walls ran in a circuit of about 10 miles (16 km) with four large suburbs lying outside. The Japanese invaded in 1937, and many gardens were again devastated by the end of the war. In the early 1950s, restoration was done on the Humble Administrator's Garden and the Lingering Garden.


== Administrative divisions ==

The urban core of Suzhou is informally called the "Old Town". It is Gusu District. Suzhou Industrial Park is to the east of the old town, and Suzhou High & New Technology Development Zone is to the west. In 2000, the original Wu County was divided into two districts including Xiangcheng and Wuzhong. They now form the northern and southern parts of the city of Suzhou.In 2012, the original Wujiang City became Wujiang District of Suzhou City.
Suzhou is one of the most prosperous cities in China. Its development has a direct correlation with the growth of its satellite cities, including Kunshan, Taicang, Changshu, and Zhangjiagang, which together with the city of Suzhou form the Suzhou prefecture. The Suzhou prefecture is home to many high-tech enterprises.


== Geography ==
Suzhou is on the Lake Tai Plain south of the Yangtze River, about 100 km (60 mi) to the west of Shanghai and just over 200 km (120 mi) east of Nanjing.


=== Climate ===
Suzhou has a four-season humid subtropical climate with hot, humid summers and cool, cloudy, damp winters with occasional snowfall (Köppen climate classification Cfa). Northwesterly winds blowing from Siberia during winter can cause temperatures to fall below freezing at night, while southerly or southwesterly winds during the summer can push temperatures above 35 °C (95 °F). The hottest temperature recorded since 1951 was at 41.0 °C (106 °F) on 7 August 2013, and the lowest at −9.8 °C (14 °F) on 16 January 1958.


== Cityscape and environment ==

		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		


=== Classical Gardens of Suzhou ===

Suzhou is famous for its over 60 Classical Gardens, collectively a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The city has the Most UNESCO-recognized gardens in the world.The Humble Administrator's Garden and Lingering Garden are among the four most famous classical gardens in China. The Canglang Pavilion, Lion Grove Garden, Humble Administrator's Garden and Lingering Garden, respectively representing the garden styles of the Song, Yuan, Ming, and Qing dynasties, are called the four most famous gardens in Suzhou. Other gardens inscribed on the World Heritage List include the Couple's Retreat Garden, the Garden of Cultivation, and the Retreat and Reflection Garden.


=== Temples ===
Hanshan Temple
Xiyuan Temple
Xuanmiao Temple
Lingyanshan Temple
Chongyuan Temple
Taipingfang Mosque (太平坊清真寺)


=== Canals and historic districts ===

The Suzhou section of the Jiangnan Canal, Grand Canal (China), includes ten city gates and over 20 stone bridges of traditional design and historic areas that have been well preserved, as well as temples and pavilions. 
 There are a full 24 waterways in Suzhou near the Grand Canal.In 2015, both 800-year-old Pingjiang Road Historical Block (平江路) and 1,200-year-old Shantang Street Scenic Area (山塘街) were added to the list of China's "National Historic and Cultural Streets".Pingjiang Road runs parallel to the Pingjiang River for 1.5 kilometers and is lined with homes and some teahouses. Shantang Street, over twice as long at 3.8 km, is described by the BBC as  retaining "the alluring qualities of an old canal-side street: whitewashed buildings are completed by red-tasselled lanterns that swing softly in the breeze, adding to the charm of the river bank".

Boat tours are offered on the waterways of this city that was dubbed the "Venice of the East" by Marco Polo because of its criss-crossing canals and stone bridges. The Grand Canal (from Beijing to Zhejiang province) is a UNESCO World Heritage site.


=== Resorts and natural reserves ===
Suzhou Taihu National Tourism and Vacation Zone (苏州太湖国家旅游度假区) is in the western part of Suzhou, 15 km (9 mi) from the city center.


=== Skyscrapers ===

Gate to the East is a 301.8 meter, 74-story skyscraper in Suzhou's central business district, built in 2015 at a cost of 700 million USD and is currently the tallest building in Suzhou.


=== Pan Gate ===
Pan Gate is on the southwest corner of the Main Canal or encircling canal of Suzhou. Originally built during the Warring States Period in the state of Wu, historians estimate it to be around 2,500 years old. It is now part of the Pan Gate Scenic Area. It is known for the "three landmarks of Pan Gate". They are the Ruiguang Pagoda, the earliest pagoda in Suzhou built in 247 BC, the Wu Gate Bridge, the entrance to the gate at that time over the water passage and the highest bridge in Suzhou at the time, and the Pan Gate. The Ruigang Pagoda is constructed of brick with wooden platforms and has Buddhist carvings at its base.


=== Baodai Bridge ===
Baodai Bridge stretches across the Tantai Lake in the suburbs of Suzhou. To raise money to finance the bridge, the magistrate donated his expensive belt, hence the name. The bridge was first built in 806 A.D. in the Tang Dynasty and has 53 arches with a length of 317 meters. It was made out of stone from Jinshan Mountain and is the longest standing bridge of its kind in China. The bridge was included on the list of national monuments (resolution 5-285) in 2001.


=== Tiger Hill ===
The Tiger Hill is known for its natural environment and historical sites. The hill is so named because it is said to look like a crouching tiger. Another legend states that a white tiger appeared on the hill to guard it following the burial The hill has been a tourist destination for hundreds, if not thousands, of years, as is evident from the poetry and calligraphy carved into rocks on the hill. The Song Dynasty poet, Su Shi said, "It is a lifelong pity if having visited Suzhou you did not visit Tiger Hill."


=== Pagodas ===
Yunyan Pagoda (or Huqiu Tower) built in 961 is a Chinese pagoda built on Tiger Hill in Suzhou. It has several other names, including the "Leaning Tower of China" (as referred to by historian O.G. Ingles) and the Yunyan Temple Tower. The tower rises to a height of 47 m (154 ft). It is a seven-story octagonal building built with blue bricks. In more than a thousand years the tower has gradually slanted due to forces of nature. Now the top and bottom of the tower vary by 2.32 meters. The entire structure weighs some 7,000,000 kilograms (15,000,000 lb), supported by internal brick columns. However, the tower leans roughly 3 degrees due to the cracking of two supporting columns.Beisi Pagoda or North Temple Pagoda is a Chinese pagoda at Bao'en Temple in Suzhou. It rises nine stories in a height of 76 m (249 ft). It is the tallest Chinese pagoda south of the Yangtze river.
Twin Pagodas (苏州双塔) lie in the Dinghui Temple Lane in the southeastern corner of the city proper of Suzhou. They are artistic and natural as they are close at hand. One of them is called Clarity-Dispensing Pagoda and the other Beneficence Pagoda and they are in the same form of building. There are many legends about the one-thousand-year-old pagodas. It is charming that the exquisite and straight Twin Pagoda look like two inserted writing brushes. There was originally a single-storey house with three rooms just like a writing brush holder with the shadows of the two pagodas reclining on its roof at sunset. To the east of the pagoda is a square five-storeyed bell building built in the Ming Dynasty which is exactly like a thick ink stick. So there is a saying that "the Twin Pagodas are as writing brushes while the bell building as ink stick".


=== Museums ===
The city's major museums include the Suzhou Museum (designed by I. M. Pei), Suzhou Silk Museum, and Suzhou Museum of Opera and Theatre.


=== Hospitals ===
As a result of its recent rapid population increase, healthcare demand in Suzhou is increasing rapidly. In July 2019, Washington University School of Medicine announced a collaboration with Huici Health Management Co., and the Xiangcheng District, to open the new Huici Medical Center, which will include a 1,000-bed hospital for adult and pediatric patients. Once the hospital is unveiled, Washington University doctors in St. Louis will be able to provide long-distance health-care services to patients in China through a telemedicine program.


== Demographics ==
The population of Suzhou is predominantly Han Chinese. The official language of broadcast, instruction, etc. is Mandarin Chinese, although many speak a local dialect known as Suzhounese, a member of the Wu language family. In addition to American and European expatriates, there is a large Korean community in Suzhou. The Industrial Bank of Korea (IBK) estimated that there were 15,000 Koreans in the municipality in 2014. That year 850 Korean companies operated in Suzhou, and the Koreans made up the largest number of students at the Suzhou Singapore International School.


== Economy ==
Suzhou's economy is based primarily on its large manufacturing sector—China's second largest—including iron and steel, IT and electronic equipment, and textile products. The city's service sector is notably well-developed, primarily owing to tourism, which brought in a total of RMB 152 billion of revenue in 2013. Suzhou's overall GDP exceeded RMB 1.3 trillion in 2013 (up 9.6 percent from the year previous).The city is also one of China's foremost destinations for foreign investment, based on its relative proximity to Shanghai and comparatively low operating costs. The municipal government has enacted various measures to encourage FDI in a number of manufacturing (e.g. pharmaceutical, electronic goods, automobile) and service (e.g. banking, logistics, research services) sectors. Included among these measures is a preferential tax policy for limited partnership venture capital enterprises in the Suzhou Industrial Park.


=== Development zones ===


==== Suzhou Industrial Park ====

The Suzhou Industrial Park (SIP) is the largest cooperative project between the Chinese and Singaporean governments. It is beside Jinji Lake, which lies to the east of the Suzhou Old City. On 26 February 1994, Vice Premier Li Lanqing and Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew represented China and Singapore respectively in signing the Agreement to jointly develop Suzhou Industrial Park (originally called the Singapore Industrial Park). The project officially commenced on 12 May in the same year. SIP has a jurisdiction area of 288 km2 (111 sq mi), of which, the China-Singapore cooperation area covers 80 km2 (31 sq mi) with a planned residential population of 1.2 million.SIP is home to the Suzhou Dushu Lake Science and Education Innovation District, an area of universities and higher education institutions, including Soochow University and Xi'an Jiaotong-Liverpool University. Suzhou Industrial Park is also a popular residential district for many foreigners who work and live in Suzhou, as well as 'new Suzhou' residents who migrated to the area in search of work opportunities.


==== Suzhou Industrial Park Export Processing Zone ====
The Suzhou Industrial Park Export Processing Zone was approved to be established by the government in April 2000, with a planning area of 2.9 km2 (1.1 sq mi). It is in Suzhou Industrial Park set up by China and Singapore. Inside the Export Processing Zone, all the infrastructures are of high standard.


==== Suzhou New District ====

The Suzhou New District was established in 1990. In November 1992, the zone was approved to be the national-level hi-tech industrial zone. By the end of 2007, foreign-invested companies had a registered capital worth of US$13 billion, of which US$6.8 billion was paid in. SND hosts now more than 1,500 foreign companies. Some 40 Fortune 500 companies set up 67 projects in the district.


== Sports ==
Suzhou Dongwu currently play in China League Two, the third division of Chinese football. The 13,000 seat Suzhou Industrial Park Sports Arena will be one of the venues for the 2019 FIBA Basketball World Cup.


== Transportation ==


=== Railway ===
Suzhou is on the Shanghai-Nanjing corridor which carries three parallel railways. Suzhou railway station, near the city center, is among the busiest passenger stations in China. It is served by the Beijing–Shanghai railway (mostly "conventional" trains to points throughout China) and the Shanghai-Nanjing intercity railway (high-speed D- and G-series trains providing frequent service primarily between Shanghai and Nanjing). It takes only 25 minutes to reach Shanghai railway station on the fastest G-series trains and less than 1 hour to Nanjing.
The Suzhou North railway station, a few kilometers to the north, is on the Beijing–Shanghai high-speed railway (opened 2011), served by high-speed trains to Beijing, Qingdao, etc.
Other stations on the Beijing–Shanghai railway and the Shanghai–Nanjing intercity railway serve other points in the same corridor within Suzhou Prefecture-level city, such as Kunshan. In and between Suzhou and Kunshan South railway station, Suzhou Industrial Park railway station now also becomes an important station for people visiting and living in the areas.
The northern part of the city, including such county-level cities as Zhangjiagang, Changshu and Taicang, presently has no rail service. However, plans exist for a cross-Yangtze railway from Nantong to the Shanghai metropolitan area (the Shanghai–Nantong railway), which will run through most of these county-level cities. Construction work is expected to start in 2013 and to take five and a half years.


=== Highways ===
The Nanjing-Shanghai Expressway connects Suzhou with Shanghai, alternatively, there is the Yangtze Riverine Expressway and the Suzhou-Jiaxing-Hangzhou Expressway. In 2005, the Suzhou Outer Ring was completed, linking the peripheral county-level cities of Taicang, Kunshan, and Changshu. China National Highway 312 also passes through Suzhou.


=== Air transport ===
Suzhou is served by three airports, Sunan Shuofang International Airport (co-owned by Wuxi and Suzhou), Shanghai Hongqiao International Airport ( one hour drive ), Shanghai Pudong International Airport ( two hours drive ).


=== Water transport ===

Port of Suzhou, on the right bank of the Yangtze River, dealt with 428 million tons of cargo and 5.86 million TEU containers in 2012, which made it the busiest inland river port in the world by annual cargo tonnage and container volume.


=== Metro ===

The Suzhou Rail Transit currently has four lines in operation and five other lines under construction. The masterplan consists of nine independent lines. Line 1 started operation on April 28, 2012, Line 2 started operation on December 28, 2013, and Line 4 started operation in 2017. As of March 2020, Line 5, Line 6, Line 7 and Line 8 and Line S1 are under construction at the same time.


=== Tram ===

Suzhou Tram system has two routes in the Suzhou New District.


=== Bus ===
Suzhou has public bus routes that run into all parts of the city. Fares are flat rated, usually 1 Yuan for a non-air-conditioned bus and 2 Yuan for an air-conditioned one. The Suzhou BRT, a 25-kilometre (16 mi) bus rapid transit system opened in 2008, operates 5 lines using elevated busways and bus-only lanes throughout the city.


== Culture ==

Opera: Kunqu originates in the Suzhou region, as does the much later Suzhou Opera. Ballad-singing, or Suzhou pingtan, is a local form of storytelling that mixes singing (accompanied by the pipa and sanxian) with portions in spoken dialect.
Silk: throughout China's Imperial past, Suzhou silk has been associated with high-quality silk products, supplying silks to ancient royal families. By the 13th century, Suzhou was already the center of the profitable silk trade.
Song brocade: Suzhou's Song brocade, with its flashy colors, exquisite patterns, strong and soft texture, is one of China's three famous brocades, together with Nanjing Yun brocade and Sichuan Shu brocade. Suzhou's brocade production can be traced back to the Five Dynasties. It prospered in the Song Dynasty. After the government moved the capital southward, the country's political and cultural center moved to the Yangtze River area. To cope with the special need of artists, a type of very thin brocade for decorating paintings emerged in Suzhou. These brocades and paintings have been preserved. Whenever people talked about brocade, they mentioned the Song Dynasty, and thus Song brocade got its name and has been well-known ever since.
Handicrafts: Suzhou embroidery, fans, Chinese musical instruments, scroll mounting, lanterns, mahogany furniture, jade carving, silk tapestry, traditional painting pigments of Jiangenxutang Studio, the New Year's wood-block prints of Taohuawu Studio.
Paintings
Calligraphic art
Cuisine: Yangcheng Lake large crab
Suzhou Silk Hand Embroidery Art
Suzhou is the original place of "Jasmine", a song sung by Chinese singers or actresses thousands of times on the occasions of almost every important meetings or celebrations. Jasmine is the symbol of Suzhou as well as Tai Hu Lake.
Suzhou Gardens: Gardens in Suzhou have an ancient history. The first garden in Suzhou belonged to the emperor of Wu State in Spring and Autumn Period (600 BC). More than 200 gardens existed in Suzhou between the 16th and 18th centuries. Gardens in Suzhou were built according to the style of Chinese Paintings. Every view in a garden can be seen as a piece of Chinese Painting and the whole garden is a huge piece of Chinese Paintings. At present, the Humble Administrator's Garden, built in 16th, is the largest private garden in Suzhou. It belonged to by Wang Xianchen, an imperial censor.
Suzhou embroidery together with embroidery of Hunan, Sichuan and Guangdong are called as the "Four Famous Embroideries". Suzhou tapestry method is done in fine silks and gold thread. Other art forms found in this area are sculpture, Song brocade, jade and rosewood carving.
The Suzhou Museum has a rich collection of relics from many eras. The collection includes revolutionary records, stele carving, folk customs, drama and verse, Suzhou embroidery, silk cloth, gardens, coins and Buddhist artifacts.

text.wiki:
Pan Gate, Pan Men, or Panmen (simplified Chinese: 盘门; traditional Chinese: 盤門; pinyin: Pán Mén; Suzhou Wu: Boe men, Wu Chinese pronunciation: [bø mən]) is a historical landmark in Suzhou, Jiangsu, China.  It is located on the south-west corner of the Main Canal or encircling canal of Suzhou. Originally built during the Spring and Autumn period in the state of Wu, historians estimate it to be around 2,500 years old.  It is now part of the Pan Gate Scenic Area.  It is known for the "three landmarks of Pan Gate".  They are the Ruiguang Pagoda, the earliest pagoda in Suzhou built in 247, the Wu Gate Bridge, the entrance to the gate at that time over the water passage and the highest bridge in Suzhou at the time, and Pan Gate.  The Ruigang Pagoda is constructed of brick with wooden platforms and has simple Buddhist carvings at its base.Pan Gate is part of the ancient city wall built in 514 BCE that surrounded and protected Suzhou.  Pan Gate was the only entrance to the wall that surrounded ancient Suzhou.  It is also known in China for its architecture.  It is so famous for its complex of both land and water city gates that many times, people directly refer to it as the "Land and Water Gate". In order to attract more tourists, in recent years, the city of Suzhou has renovated the old wall and built many other attractions around the original gate in the Pan Gate Scenic Area.
The present structure was built in the 11th year of the reign of Zhizheng (1333-1370 AD) at the end of the Yuan dynasty (1271-1368).

trip: 盘门在苏州城南面城墙上偏西的一座水陆城门，是苏州仅存的古城门遗蹟和中国唯一保存完整的古水陆城门，绝美的景色。
办了苏州旅游休闲年卡，第一站来到市区的古城墙盘门景区，其中盘门是元明清三代陆续修建的遗构，是中国唯一保留完整的水陆并列古城门，非常值得一看。深秋的季节，景区内还有黄澄澄的银杏和枫红可供欣赏！
这次来到苏州，入住吴宫太平洋酒店， 这个饭店很美，同时与盘门相连再一起， 房客可以自由进出盘门景点，非常方便! 盘门真的很美，里头的建筑也是苏式风情， 进入盘门就感觉与世隔绝，相当放松! 里头还有很多老年人在运动或是耍剑，十分有趣! 这景点也可以乘坐苏州好行抵达， 或是地铁4号线南门站步行前往!!
盘门是春秋战国时代风云人物伍子胥所建，公元前514年，也就是2500年前！盘门是春秋战国时代的原址，也是中国唯一保留最完整的水城门。晚上站在城门上，“水陆萦迴”高高挂上，凉风习习，看着城墙，再看着城下，仿佛置身在2500年前“瓮中捉鳖”的吴国霸气之中。 我给5颗星。如果喜欢风景、喜欢历史古迹、文化遗产、听故事，不妨到此一游，犹如身在历史场景中，了解一下古人的智慧。
景区工作人员太差劲，头天买的门票，由于时间关系第二天去，导游说没关系，可以进去的，结果不让进，要跟她们市场部联系，导游进行沟通也不行，打了很多电话都没人接，我们在大风中等了很久，结果打了110才让进，想说的是如果有紧急状况怎么办？无人接听电话。
我住在附近的酒店，旁边就是这个景区。从酒店出发，我可以通过后门进入这个地方。我很开心发觉这个地方。它在几年前经过翻新。你可以看到建筑物，宝塔，湖泊，花园。它们保存得很好，很干净。我爬到宝塔的顶部，欣赏周围的美景。我甚至有机会在这里，响起巨大的钟声（需要一小笔捐款）。我很高兴，没有看到人随地吐痰，扔垃圾或小孩在花园里撒尿。
听解说员说城里是古时的孙权，所以能看到年代久远的城池，里头有座宝塔，城外有雕像与一座古桥，夜晚从桥上往两头看过去的景色非常迷人，名符其实的烟雨江南！
住的酒店和景区是连通的，酒店本身就是很有特色的建筑，建筑的设计也很有园林的风格，所以感觉上酒店就是在园林里。
盘门景区有著名的三景：盘门 吴门桥 瑞光塔 盘门是国内现存保存完好的的水陆古城门 吴门桥是单孔石桥 跨度很高
不算是苏州最有名的景点，其实却还是蛮好玩的。非常少见的“水陆城门”构造，也可以随着马道走上城墙，很有些当年守城小卫的赶脚。
盘门是位于苏州古城南面城墙上偏西的一座水陆城门，门前是古老的京杭大运河，此乃苏州仅存的古城门遗蹟和中国唯一保存完整的古水陆城门。 城门，吴门桥，瑞光寺塔三个景点结合为所谓的盘门三景，若对中国历史有兴趣的朋友值得花些时间去那儿走走。
广大的花园在这个季节非常美丽，游客不是很多，所以逛起来很悠闲。最值得参观的就是那城门，有着导游带我们解说，可以了解当时的人的智慧，如何有效的防御入侵，还可以看到存留的机关和砲口，如何一层层阻止敌人的攻入，是一种非常有趣的历史角度。城门外还有美丽的河畔步道可以走走，但河里散发出来的味道有点不敢令人恭维。
上海东方卫视的极限挑战在这里拍摄 挺好的 还有湖南卫视我们来了也在这里拍摄 景区人不多 还可以 值得推荐 周边就是树木丛生 夏天来这里不错 适合
当地旅行社先带团员去蚕丝店晃极久的时间 重点式未事先说明有购物站 到盘门景区时已是晚上 真不知道是在看什么 走路不会跌倒就阿弥陀佛了
风景优美，值得一去，周围交通便利，餐厅也有一些，周末出去放松，约几位好友一起喝茶聊天，也有很多值得拍照的地方，放松休闲的好地方
有历史底蕴，盘门是苏州保存的较好的一座水路城门，景色也不错，大运河尽收眼底，值得大家一去。盘门的夜景特别漂亮，建议去看看。
过年的时候，不想去拙政园，留园之类的人头攒动的地方看热闹，我决定来盘门。结果来了之后觉得很惊喜，门票不贵，但是景色一点逊色。有塔有古城门，有园林有山，处处体现出苏州园林的特色。关键是人不错，旅游体验很超值啊！
苏州有名的景点，水路城门，构造蛮有巧思的，但还是要听导游讲解才会比较清楚。 整体的环境还算干净，景区也有免费的WIFI，交通还算方便>
盘门为现在唯一水陆并存的城门，有“北看长城之雄,南看盘门之秀”之说。横跨运河的“ 吴门桥”、临流照影的“ 瑞光寺塔”，并称盘门三景。景区内景色秀丽、古木葱翠。
跟团游，而且是团费超低的哪种，不过这个景点还是指的一看的，是一个古代的历史城墙，有些历史的意义。下面有一条很短的河道，有摆渡的小船，不知道正常什么价格，但建议不必要乘坐，因为太短了。
盘门真是挺让人惊喜的，有古塔有古城墙也有现代规划的园林，感觉真的很好。感觉来盘门的游客不是很多，所以整个非常大的景区里都给人一种轻松自在的休闲感。景区管理方也都做了很好，整个景区干净惬意，非常棒！
盘门的地理位置很好，在河边，周围也没有高大的建筑物，很古朴闲适的一个公园，亭台轩榭，很有感觉。尤其早晨黄昏在里面走走感觉特别好。
来到苏洲一定也要去磐门走走 非常漂亮 园区内很多地方都很适合拍照 当然有很多历史遗留的文物 苏洲盘门值得推荐
盘门景区位于苏州古城区的西南角，门票40元，进入东门就可以看到雄伟的瑞光塔，北宋古塔，苏州最古。其中的国宝真珠舍利宝幢现在苏博，是镇馆之宝。登塔6元，但是只能上一小半，塔窗无法靠近远眺，很坑。盘门号称是水陆法门，陆门水门并立，非常具有文物价值，站在瓮城上，想想当年的伍子胥吧。
深秋的盘门夜是迷人的! 历史写在每一处石头城墙的痕迹上. 清风吹拂、银杏叶在灯光下挥洒金黄! 站在拱桥上能深深的感触到千年文化积累下的内蕴.
这次去苏州最让人失望的景点，就为了看二栋楼花了50元，还不如门口的吴宫太平洋酒店好看，5元的话就进去吧！,不然别浪费时间金钱了...
由于是公司活动，跟团而行，比较匆匆，基本上是走马观花型的。但即使如此也能发现这里的园林比较有特色，假山、庭园、小桥、流水，要有的也都有了，而且不乏设计，也有年代。
从吴宫太平洋酒店可凭房卡直接进入，古意盎然，虽有很多是80年代重修，但保留了原建筑风格（城墙和塔基都有部分是明清或更早的砖料）
盘门是位于苏州古城南面城墙上偏西的一座水陆城门，门前临古老的京杭大运河，是苏州仅存的古城门遗迹和中国唯一保存完整的古水陆城门。 盘门、吴门桥和瑞光寺塔共同构成盘门三景。
景区在酒店后面，达到很方便，而且酒店入住免费进圆，江南园林的特色，很精致，山山水水，亭台楼榭，水中鱼儿非常大、老的城墙，还可以在某时间段听到昆曲表演
就在苏州吴官泛太平洋酒店后门，酒店客人免费游览，2小时足够游览。可以跟着旅游团蹭导游讲解。正门进去不远的塔有悠久历史，但不开放了好像。游客通常不多，和拙政园相比不会熙熙攘攘。
盘门以前不是太了解，住了旁边的酒店可以免费参观盘门。这里有园林，城墙，大炮还有亭子，似乎带你回到了几百年前，用现在的时髦名词讲：穿越。
乍看，有点单调，有点冷门。但如果能读些水路城门的历史，以及伍子胥时代如何通过城门如何御敌的资料，再去看，会显得更有趣些。
在这个景区里你能了解到姑苏城的历史，人文和各方面有意思的事物，所以推荐大家可以去走走，慢慢细细的品味一下这个人文景点大餐
苏州盘门景区是去苏州必去的景点之一，古城墙，古建筑很有味道，特别适合春天去游玩，泛舟湖上，别有一番韵味。强烈推荐
盘门很体现苏州古城味道,没有别的景点人多, 慢慢走在二千多年的古城墙上, 想着关于这座古城的美丽传说, 感觉很棒! 有空值得一游
十一节去的，住在旁边的吴宫酒店，两者风格接近，从后门进去，是酒店的免费景点和后花园，吃饱早饭，踱进去散步，居然人也不多，较前一日在拙政园和狮子林比天壤之别，清净悠闲，景色宜人，让我们全家因此也多喜欢酒店三分。
因为本人是南方（广东）人。之前一直呆在那边。读书的时候很憧憬江南烟雨。于是乎就来到了江南 江苏浙江都有去，。。印象比较深刻的就是盘门伍子胥的吧 有很古城的味道也有点感觉之前吴国的阵势···恩恩 不错
我才来苏州时跑遍了各大园林景点，可能是园林早有耳闻，所以也不觉得怎样，但是去了苏州盘门景点觉得真不错，比较特别，是一般城市都没有的，可以说也是苏州一个特色景点吧。所以来的游客到苏州，除了去看园林，一定要去盘门玩玩，因为它值得一游。
春天的时候去的，去的那天下着毛毛雨，春天最适合去苏州了。花红柳嫩。。。总的感觉特别好，阴雨蒙蒙的时侯去苏州别有一番滋味。。。
和朋友两个人自己去玩的。没有爬那个古塔，下午4点才去的，都没有什么游客了，所以感觉偌大的园子里就几个人，玩得很爽，拍照也很顺利。古城墙很有气势，站在上面很有感觉，春天花草树木也都非常漂亮。没有有船，好像那下也下班了，总之挺不错的。
这个公园挺大的，有山有水，亭台楼阁错落，不仅可以了解历史，只是去散散步也很好。交通也很方便，总体来说是个挺实惠的景点。
那里的风景不错，有古建筑和围墙，适合散心，特别是围墙上的走到，两边都是碧绿的青草，很容易陶醉其中，阳光更是不错哦。
盘门景点还是不错的， 价格便宜，景区又大! 而且还有免费的《瓮中捉鳖》表演，游客也可以参与其中！ 景区内的景点也比较不错！ 如果自己去玩，安排半天的时间最合适！
盘门的风景也不错。觉得在苏州生活以及定居的人很幸福。因为苏州的景点很多，环境不错，小桥流水的，很适合人去那里定居。
在苏州古城区，不过离拙政园、狮子林有点距离，打车是起步价能到。怎么说呢，很小的景点，苏州的古城区的景点都不大，古城墙的残垣断壁似乎还保留着当年的气势。逛一圈快一点半小时可能就OK了
我的童年是在这个景点度过的，可以说是这一带的扛把子。 记得小时候去玩的时候是不需要门票的，所以那连绵的城墙就是我们躲猫猫的最好场所了。 水陆两栖城门的设计，古往今来，绝无仅有。
古城啊！水陆防线啊！把古人的才智体现的！！！听说投名状的一个场景也是在这里拍的哦！！！嘎嘎！在这还有个亮点“将军装老外”见图。。。
团购去的苏州，之前小时候去的记忆已经模糊了。盘门三景是旅行线路中一个重点景点，主要还是看看古城墙，想象“瓮中捉鳖”的场景。总的来说跟团有点仓促，没有什么时间细心看看，其实里面还蛮大的，可以花点时间看看。
这是个值得去的景区，很有苏州代表性。景色不错，环境优雅，苏州园林很不错！是苏州必去景点之一啊！最好在天气好的春天去。非常美丽
融合苏州园林和吴文化的经典之作，原来的盘门三景，国家4 A级景区。坐落在苏州市区，交通便利，一年四季吸引众多国内外游客。
大门和大院提供了古老的风景区，包括寺庙，花园，湖泊和城市大门（我认为）。 从现代的角度来看，我觉得这个地方比不起眼的没有主题的管理员花园要好得多。这样可以更好地维护和更好地设计。
经过修复的苏州历史名城大门，沿水路而建。整个地区都是历史悠久的，有一些遗址（古老的城墙，桥梁）证明了这一点。散步很漂亮，很漂亮。到了晚上，灯光为该地区增添了色彩。
市区内一个非常宜人的公园。如果天气晴朗，最好在下午漫步，它毗邻Pan Pacific Hotel，但这个公园里充满了历史文物。瑞安塔有800年的历史，古老的城墙可以追溯到吴王朝。花园布置得很好，尽管它可能不像一些著名的联合国教科文组织花园那样出名，但同样令人印象深刻，我真的很喜欢在这里的时间。
这个风景名胜区包括许多水道和池塘，一座塔和一个巨大的设防门。该地区是苏州古城的一部分，被称为亚洲威尼斯。威尼斯政府赠送给苏州市的是一个真正的缆车。它宜人的公园和露台绝对会让您整日漫步，看着池塘里的金鱼，在树下休息。

Panmen Gate位于Gusu Garden（Gusu Yuan）的西南角。它是苏州城墙中唯一仍然存在的主要部分的一部分，曾经作为防水墙保护城市的水闸。大门内有许多建筑物，其中最重要的是瑞冈塔。在门的南边是吴门桥（5盖茨大桥），这是苏州最高的拱形桥，从那里你可以看到穿过运河的船只以及隔壁的公园。剩下的墙只有大约300米，所以看到它不值得一次特别的旅行 - 其余的理由也不合理。

text.wiki:
Jinji Lake (simplified Chinese: 金鸡湖; traditional Chinese: 金雞湖; pinyin: Jīnjī Hú, literally Golden Rooster Lake) is a small fresh water lake located in the central part of Suzhou Industrial Park, Jiangsu, China. It occupies an area of 7.18 square kilometers and its average depth is about 2.5 to 3 meters. There are two man-made islands in the lake.


== Tourism ==
The lake is one of the largest inland lakes in China. The northern and western shores of the lake is concentrated on shopping and entertainment amenities. The green spaces are along the eastern and southern shore.


== See also ==
Dushu Lake
Suzhou Ferris Wheel


== References ==


== External links ==
 Media related to Jinji Lake at Wikimedia Commons

text.wiki:
The Canglang Pavilion (simplified Chinese: 沧浪亭; traditional Chinese: 滄浪亭; pinyin: Cāng Làng Tíng; Suzhou Wu: Tshaon laon din, Wu Chinese pronunciation: [tsʰɑ̃ lɑ̃ din]), variously translated as the Great Wave Pavilion, Surging Wave Pavilion, or Blue Wave Pavilion, is one of the Classical Gardens of Suzhou that are jointly recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It is located at 3 Canglangting Street in Suzhou, Jiangsu province, China.


== History ==
The Canglang Pavilion was built in 1044 CE by the Song dynasty poet Su Shunqin (1008–1048), on the site of a pre-existing imperial flower garden c 960 CE. It is the oldest of the UNESCO gardens in Suzhou, keeping its original Song dynasty layout. The name is derived from a verse in the poem Fishermen by Qu Yuan (ca. 340 BCE-278 BCE), a poet from the southern state of Chu during the Warring States period, in his book Songs of the South, "If the Canglang River is dirty I wash my muddy feet; If the Canglang River is clean I wash my ribbon". This verse alludes to an honest official who removes himself from politics rather than act in a corrupt manner. Su Shunqing choose this to express his feelings after his removal from office.
After his death the garden passed through many owners and fell into disuse until 1696 CE when it was restored by Song Luo, the governor of Jiangsu Province. In 1827 ownership was transferred to governor Tao Zhu and again in 1873 ownership was transferred to governor Zhang Shusheng.  In 1955 the garden was opened to the public and in 2000 it was added to the UNESCO World Cultural Heritage Monuments.


== Design ==
The 1.6 ha garden is divided into two main sections. The garden is sited on a branch of the Fengxi Stream which forms a lotus pond. The garden has 108 windows each one with a unique design.

text.wiki:
The Classical Gardens of Suzhou are a group of gardens in Suzhou region, Jiangsu province, China, which have been added to the UNESCO World Heritage List.
Spanning a period of almost one thousand years, from the Northern Song to the late Qing dynasties (11th-19th century), these gardens, most of them built by scholars, standardized many of the key features of classical Chinese garden design with constructed landscapes mimicking natural scenery of rocks, hills and rivers with strategically located pavilions and pagodas.The elegant aesthetics and subtlety of these scholars' gardens and their delicate style and features are often imitated by various gardens in other parts of China, including the various Imperial Gardens, such as those in the Chengde Mountain Resort.  According to UNESCO, the gardens of Suzhou "represent the development of Chinese landscape garden design over more than two thousand years," and they are the "most refined form" of garden art.These landscape gardens flourished in the mid-Ming to early-Qing dynasties, resulting in as much as 200 private gardens.  Today, there are 69 preserved gardens in Suzhou, and all of them are designated as protected "National Heritage Sites."  In 1997 and 2000, eight of the finest gardens in Suzhou along with one in the nearby ancient town of Tongli  were selected by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site to represent the art of Suzhou-style classical gardens.Famous Suzhou garden designers include Zhang Liang, Ji Cheng, Ge Yuliang, and Chen Congzhou.


== The gardens ==


== Comprehensive monitoring plan ==
The site is monitored following a comprehensive monitoring plan and there is provision for both the routine maintenance and
programmed conservation projects for all of the gardens. The Suzhou Municipal Administrative Bureau of Gardens is responsible for this.
